Then $$$a = [2, 3, 2, 3, 1]$$$ and $$$2 \\cdot 1 + 3 \\cdot 3 + 2 \\cdot 2 + 3 \\cdot 4 + 1 \\cdot 2 = 29$$$.In the second example, you don't need to use the reverse operation. $$$13 \\cdot 2 + 37 \\cdot 4 = 174$$$.In the third example, you can reverse the subarray $$$[3, 5]$$$. You are given two arrays of integers,  *a* and *b*, both of length *n*. You can reverse one continuous subarray within array *a*.  Your goal is to find the subarray to reverse so that the sum of the products of corresponding elements in the arrays ($$\sum_{i=1}^n a_i \cdot b_i$$) is maximized.

Input:

* The first line contains an integer *n* (1 ≤ *n* ≤ 5000).
* The second line contains *n* integers, representing the elements of array *a* (1 ≤ *a<sub>i</sub>* ≤ 10<sup>7</sup>).
* The third line contains *n* integers, representing the elements of array *b* (1 ≤ *b<sub>i</sub>* ≤ 10<sup>7</sup>).

Output:

* Print a single integer, which is the maximum possible sum after reversing at most one subarray of *a*.
You have two lists of numbers. You can reverse one section of the first list. What arrangement of the lists will result in the largest sum of the products of corresponding numbers?
